|Title=Know the circumstances and different diagnostic criteria (with particular reference to children).

Diabetes may be diagnosed in the following situations:

1/ Screening


2/ Fasting venous blood glucose ≥ 1.26 g/l on two occasions.  

3/ Orally induced hyperglycaemia if blood glucose 2 hours after oral loading is greater than or equal to 2 g/l [11 mmol/l].

OGTT is indicated in the following cases:

- pregnancy

- fasting blood glucose between 1.10 and 1.26 g/l [6 to 7 mmol/l].


4/ Emergency situations in symptomatic patients with blood glucose levels of 2 g/l [11 mmol/l] or more

In children, cardinal syndrome is often present, but is difficult to recognise in infants.

Ketoacidosis is often present at diagnosis, especially in children aged < 5 years.


<ref>CEEDMM, 2019</ref>

question.title: When is Oral Glucose Tolerance Test (OGTT) indicated?
question.description: According to the provided text, in which situations is OGTT indicated?

option_a.title: When fasting blood glucose levels are between 1.10 and 1.26 g/l [6 to 7 mmol/l]
option_a.description: A situation where OGTT is indicated

option_b.title: When symptoms of diabetic ketoacidosis are present
option_b.description: A situation where OGTT is indicated

option_c.title: When blood glucose levels are 2 g/l [11 mmol/l] or more in emergency situations
option_c.description: A situation where OGTT is indicated

option_d.title: When type 1 diabetes is diagnosed
option_d.description: A situation where OGTT is not indicated

correct_option.title: When fasting blood glucose levels are between 1.10 and 1.26 g/l [6 to 7 mmol/l]
